post_excerpt: Since the meltdown in the investment markets some 30 years ago in 1987, there has been a lot of soul searching among fund companies to produce new and ritzy products that will suit the contemporary investor. The modern frame of operation takes place in a world where time and money is the essence, and making a quick buck is the preferred result.

Now an Independent Financial Adviser, he is here to share his views, suggestions and recommendations with those curious about investment in this vast jungle of opportunities."][/lvca_team][vc_separator color="grey" align="align_center" style="" border_width="" el_width=""][vc_column_text]<strong>Making the Right Choice</strong>

Buying Stocks &amp; Shares

<strong>ADVICE</strong>: Take the plunge… dive into the best stock markets in the world, buy stocks and shares… it’s inevitable that they will definitely affect your wealth. This is all very well, but where to begin? Which markets do you choose? There are a million questions to consider. Here are but a few.

Are things really flying in Brazil? Is mining in the Philippines about to collapse? Is China overcooked? Is the United States of America really bankrupt with its massive bond debts in the hands of China? Which sectors are the ones that will perform? Is it still IT, Commodities, Energy stocks, Consumables, Construction? Or perhaps it is time again for Communications?

The fact is the list is endless…

What to buy, when to buy, where to buy, these are all million-dollar questions. Perhaps we should say “million yen questions” because, let’s face it, the US Dollar is clearly under threat from the Middle East. Ah, there we have it, which currency to invest in?

But let’s back-track a little, because the very first decision is actually “how to buy.”

Luckily, there is a clear path to choose for the uninitiated, and this approach will also be taken by the experienced investor as part and parcel of a more sophisticated portfolio in an effort to spread the risk among a number of investment baskets.

Step one is to look at the wide field of choice offered by Investment Funds; hundreds of stock market funds haggle for your attention. Fund managers, big and small, old and new, general and specialist, all wave their menu of choices at everyone in yet another quagmire of brilliance and confusion!

<strong>INVESTMENT FUNDS: </strong>“When America sneezes the stock markets of the world catch a cold.”

In Europe, there has always been a stock market saying: “Sell in May and go away.”

The big wide world likes to think that it is independent of the USA, and, over the years, this has increasingly become the case. The world boasts of its resilience and gloats at the relatively feeble profits in North America. It is clear that Asia is booming, with China and India as market leaders in many areas, hosting between them 1/3 of the world’s population. Then, something happens, and the ripples ensnare institutions and corporations around the globe. The press rubs salt on the open wound and the crisis festers. Then, just as we start believing that the world is doomed, the stock markets hit new record highs. All is forgiven and profits pour in again.

The fact is that the stock markets of the world, in a general sense, are indeed inter-linked, and when one big market falls, they all follow suit. It is an insipid cycle of intent.

A Stock Market choice: <strong>RISK</strong>.

“No pain, no gain” emphasizes the chances of winning or losing…

<em>High Risk</em> - means lots of profit or lots of losses. Timing is everything. No one knows all the answers, but you can have a hunch based on a pile of percolated information. High risk works both ways – when things are good, the returns are fantastic.

<em>Low Risk</em> – does not necessarily mean “small returns and small losses.” When times are good, low risk funds can also fatten the calf. But, generally, as long as money is not left to rot in safety in a plain bank account, then returns will be welcomed in the long run.

<strong>TAKING THE PLUNGE IN ASIA</strong>:      Everyone has been jumping up and down over China, India and Russia, and no wonder, because the returns have been phenomenally good in recent times.

<em>The conclusion</em>: If there is going to be growth in the world in general, it is going to be in Asia. Forget the sophisticated markets, go for the undeveloped and exotic countries. China is the brawn of Asia; India is the brain of Asia; and the Philippines is in the growing heart of Asia.

<strong> </strong>[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_column_text css_animation=""]

Now an Independent Financial Adviser, he is here to share his views, suggestions and recommendations with those curious about investment in this vast jungle of opportunities."][/lvca_team][vc_separator color="grey" align="align_center" style="" border_width="" el_width=""][vc_column_text]<strong>Taking the Plunge</strong>

A lesson in how money works

Are we really aware of that miracle of <strong>“compounding interest”</strong> and the <strong>Golden Rule of 72</strong>?

Einstein described the miracle of compounding as “the greatest mathematical discovery of all time” and as “the eighth wonder of the world.” He definitely knew a thing or two about how the universe ticks.

John Maynard Keynes, the economist genius, described it as “the awesome power of compound interest.”

What amazed these men was the way in which, given enough time, even apparently trivial amounts of money can turn into spectacular fortunes. The reason is simple but profound.

Take $1,000 and invest it wisely, grow it by 10% in a year, and, at the end of that year, you will have $1,100. Do the same for a second year and you will have not $1,200-but $1,210 because your 10% return on the starting $1,100 is worth $110. Do this every year for 20 years and the return in the last year will be worth $600 and the initial $1,000 will have turned into $6,700.

Now imagine that, during the first year, you put aside another $1,000 (that is only $20 a week) and set it to work alongside the first $1,000. The 19 years during which it grows at 10% a year will turn it into $6,100. The third year’s $1,000 will grow to $5,600 in 18 years and so on … in 20 years you will have amassed $64,000 by simply saving $20 a week.

The beauty of compound interest is that the longer you can let it work its magic, the greater the rewards. Although it will take you 32 years to build this savings up to $500,000, by the time another 30 years has passed, your fund will have more than doubled to a grand sum of $1,100,000. Quite a tidy sum - and all that for so little weekly!

<em>The motto is clearly “start saving now,” and do not delay…because compounding will work more in your favor the more time you have set aside for its magic.                  </em>

OK, so now we know that we should start saving…but what is this <strong>Golden Rule of 72</strong>?

Time can perform miracles with your modest savings, but then comes the revelation that if you can squeeze out a slightly better return than the 10%, then the returns are immensely     compounded. That is what the Golden Rule of 72 shows you. It is the formula for showing you how many years it will take you to double your money at a rate of compound interest.

To work this out, simply divide 72 by the interest rate you think you can achieve. At 7% it will take 10 years to double your money, while at 12% a year, it will take just 6 years.

In those last 30 years, after you have given up saving and your money is working hard while you sleep, you will double your money around four times over at just 10% a year (which is how you will get from $64,000 to $1,100,000). BUT, at 15% a year you would do it twice more again, which would turn $1,100,000 into $4,400,000.

So, now all you need to do is find investments which get you a return of 10%-15% a year.     <em>                                                                                                                                                                                                                        </em>[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_column_text css_animation=""]

<p style="text-align: left;"><strong>WANTED – Financial Independence</strong></p>
The older world calls it “retirement,” which has several depressing connotations associated with it, like it’s the end of the line, the end of an income stream, and that it’s maybe time to do the gardening.

Get Smart. Plan for a rainy day, plan for a lazy day, or that day when you don’t actually have to get off the beach, because commitments are secondary in that carefully planned “job-free” zone of life in retirement.

At the end of the day, it all depends on the individual’s will and willingness. It used to be that with the “good old” companies, a pension plan was part and parcel of the employment package… but, these days, more often than not, individuals have to make their own plans for money in retirement.
<p style="text-align: left;"><strong>“I’m too young to think about retiring.”</strong></p>
For many people, the decision to save for a pension is the most important investment decision they will ever make. Retirement may currently seem remote to you with other day-to-day financial demands seemingly more pressing. Yet, undertaking a simple and flexible retirement program, whatever your present age or future plans, is a wise and rewarding decision.
<p style="text-align: left;">“O<strong>r am I?”                                             </strong></p>
Increasing longevity, earlier retirement and higher expectations in retirement are all compounding to heighten the need to plan more effectively the financing of those “golden years.” Imagine for a moment how you would feel if, after a lifetime of work, you had insufficient funds to enjoy your hard-earned retirement.

One of the leading providers of international retirement plans estimates that an individual with a salary of $35,000 a year, with full pension entitlement, would receive a pension of 23% of pre-retirement income, which is a 77% fall in income. A report published by the Office of Fair Trading in the UK stated that in order to receive a pension targeted at two thirds of final salary at age 65, individuals would need to save a high proportion of their income each year until retirement. The amount required depends on whether or not they already have savings:

These figures show you what percentage you need to save in order to receive a retirement income equal to two thirds of the final year of a working salary.

If you started saving…

At age 25, you would need to save 10% of your income ever year till retirement.

At 30 - 13%

At 40 - 23%

At 50 - 46%

At 60 - 74%

It is clear from these figures what the “cost of delay” can be if you do not save early in life. Take note that if you wait till your 50s to start a plan, you might have to save 50% of your income to get yourself a sensible pension income. Ridiculous, you might say…but how much are you saving these days?

It is clear and obvious that the time to start a pension plan is as early as possible, and if you have not already started, then now is the time to begin.

<strong>THE AGE OLD QUESTION</strong>

The sources of pensions needed to meet our higher expectations are becoming less and less certain. Additionally, many existing company schemes penalize employees in respect of the employer’s contributions if they leave with only a few years of service.

The alternative is to start investing your money and making it grow. Seek expert know-how and give yourself the opportunity to make informed decisions based on sound advice.

After all, it is said that <strong>“if you fail to plan…you plan to fail!”</strong>

Save now, or invest, for a better future.

post_title: Brexit - A Key To A New Europe
post_content:
[vc_row full_width="" parallax="" parallax_image="" lvca_dark_bg=""][vc_column width="1/1"][lvca_team style="style2" per_line="1"][lvca_team_member member_name="Bruce Curran" member_image="272832" member_position="Independent Investment Expert" member_details="Bruce Curran has been advising companies and individuals in Asia about international fundinvestment for over 30 years. He was a Director of the Swire Group in Hong Kong and has written numerous financial articles for Merrill Lynch, The Security Bank, and The Billionaire Magazine, and he was also a regular columnist for the Business World newspaper as well as Time magazine. Now an Independent Financial Adviser, he is here to share his views, suggestions and recommendations with those curious about investment in this vast jungle of opportunities."][/lvca_team][vc_separator color="grey" align="align_center" style="" border_width="" el_width=""][vc_column_text]The Brexit Referendum vote for The United Kingdom to stay or leave the European Union was taken on 23<sup>rd</sup> June. The vote was very close, and it turned out that England and Wales were all for leaving, while Scotland and Northern Ireland voted to stay. The divisions in the country were an eye opener, and it was a shock to the British Prime Minister Mr Cameron, who was all for staying, but, despite his country-wide contacts, the United Kingdom population decided otherwise. Last Friday the UK sterling dollar exchange rate was its lowest for 31 years.

The result caused a swarm of downturns in markets in many places around the world. The London Stock Market had a brutal two-day slide, and global stock markets lost about $2 trillion in value on the day after the voting results were announced -the biggest one-day loss ever. Money poured into the safe havens of Gold and Government Bonds, Spot Gold rising 4%, while the yield on the benchmark 10-year US Treasury note fell to a low of 1.406 %, the lowest since 2012.

The Frankfurt Exchange was down 7% and Paris down 8%, while Italy and Spain both had their sharpest one-day drops ever, both down 12%, with some bank stocks falling as much as 20%. The extraordinary market reactions briefly looked as though the end of the economic world had arrived, with British banks suffering massively in particular.

Voting was actually extremely close, with 51.9% for leaving, but all in all this leaves the UK on an unknown path, and it’s certainly a massive setback to European unity.

As a back-up, the Bank of England, together with the European Central Bank, as well as the People’s Bank of China, all agreed to provide liquidity to ensure global market stability.

The Japanese Yen, traditionally a safe haven, was up 3.8% against the US Dollar, while Emerging Market currencies across Asia, Eastern Europe and also South Africa plummeted when the Brexit results were announced. The Federal reserve in the US is now unlikely to hike interest rates as a direct reaction to what changes are now happening in Europe.

In other initial reactions, oil fell 5% and copper sank 1.7%.

But, now that the ‘cat is out of the bag’, and the negative reactions to the Brexit have taken their toll, there is more calm and positivity flooding back into the markets, and the new Europe, working together with Britain, must look at all the advantages and the benefits of the new age, the revitalising of Europe, and the economic growth of the region generally.

The British government have the last say, and even though the people have voted to leave, Parliament will decide whether this will become the new reality. Also, it will take quite some time for Britain to exit the EU, assuming that this is the final decision, taking up to a couple of years according to some accounts. Then, British trade can flourish on its own footing without the shackles of Brussels.

US President Barack Obama has also got in on the act saying that he expects the world economy will be steady in the short run after Britain's decision but expressed concern about longer-term global growth.

One interesting fact emerged during the Brexit Referendum; in the heart of Europe, Gibraltar, also part of the United Kingdom, voted 96% to stay in the European Union. Gibraltar's Chief Minister, Fabian Picardo, is exploring options to keep the Territory in the EU despite the referendum.

"There are potentially different formulas out there, this is like a kaleidoscope that has not yet settled," he told the BBC.

Overall the Brexit has caused a massive shake up, and a chance for everyone to have a re-think about the economic future of a thriving Europe. Britain will link in, and will still be a vital force in the European arena. The Brexit vote was definitively an eye-opener, and now that the storm has blown over, all countries in Europe can get back to business. Britain will share in their dynamic future.
